questions.question_text: A user lives in a location that experiences frequent lightning storms. Which of the following would be the LEAST expensive solution to protect the user's computer hardware?

discussion.content: what about grounding

comments.content:
Grounding protects the human if some live wire touches exposed metal parts. For an overcurrent, the electricity is just an excess in your brown and blue wires and the yellow/green won't prevent it to happen.

Need something that can control how much voltage runs in the blue and brow wires. A surge protector or a UPS will do the job
As a UPS is more expensive than a surge protector, A is the answer

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The LEAST expensive.
Surge protector is the cheapest option and provides good hardware protection. 

D would be a good option, but is way more expensive, so not in line with the question

Selected Answer: A
A surge protector is cheaper than an uninterrupted power supply.

Grounding is good for preventing the transmission of electric charge onto hardware or people. it can protect equipment from external environmental impacts like rugs, wearing clothes susceptible to friction etc. as well as users when working with hardware plugged into main power.

Other Exam dump websites give a mix of grounding and surge protector for the answer, so IDK. 
UPS isn't the cheapest.

Selected Answer: D
I am sure this is a ups

comments.content: I believe because they asked for the least expensive the answer is a surge protector

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
It is definitely D
Per Professor Dion's tests the correct answer is D phishing

Selected Answer: D
C. Spoofing 
"Spoofing is the process of masquerading as another user or device. It is usually done for the purpose of accessing a resource to which the hacker should not have access or to get through a security device such as a firewall that may be filtering traffic based on a source IP address."

D. Phishing
Social engineering is a process in which an attacker attempts to acquire information about your network and system by social means, such as by talking to people in the organization. A social engineering attack may occur over the phone, by email, or by a visit. The intent is to acquire access information, such as user IDs and passwords. When the attempt is made through email or instant messaging, it is known as phishing and often is made to look as if it is coming from sites where users are likely to have accounts.

Both C and D are right according to FBI: 
https://www.fbi.gov/scams-and-safety/common-scams-and-crimes/spoofing-and-phishing

Selected Answer: A
0-day uses PC vulnerabilities the rest can exploit "HUMAN VULNERABILITIES" but Phishing is takes it to next level by using "PERSONAL" information to the mix
Man-in-the-middles = "PC VULNER"
SPOOFING = is more on a method of delivery, Downloading malware
PHISHING = Method of retrieval, asks for your credentials this is why PHISHING is the answer

comments.content: I selected "A" but the answer is "D"

Phishing is the tactic of sending hazardous links pretending to offer some service or impersonating a legitimate organization and getting the end user to click on them. All the other choices are out of control regarding end user decisions, making D the only choice that would make sense
spoofing exploits human trusting nature, as you pretend to be someone else. question does not make sense.

questions.question_text: Which of the following attack types exploits vulnerabilities in human nature?

A technician is securing a server room by implementing a two-factor authentication solution. Which of the following should the technician implement to provide the
BEST security for the server room?

discussion.content: D. Biometric lock (something you are) and hardware token (something you have)

comments.content: No, mantraps are better used for the inside of an entrance of a building where one would have to check-in and/or be verified before moving further, rather than at a room within the building.

discussion.content: In real life, A would probably be correct. But CompTIA always go for the biggest bang, a Bio-metric Lock, which would be expensive as hell to install.

choices.C: Security guard and entry control roster

questions.question_text: After a virus outbreak due to USB usage, a technician must deny users access to removable hard drives via USB ports as soon as possible. The technician has been asked to avoid interrupting any users. Which of the following is the BEST way for the technician to perform this security feature?

discussion.content: A. Push a group policy

CompTIA A+ 220-1002 â€“ Question42
After a virus has been spread unknowingly via USB removable hard drives, a technician is tasked with limiting removable hard drive access to certain network users. USB ports are used for many devices, including scanners, printers, and signature pads, so a
policy is created to deny access to removable hard drives only.
When testing the policy, a removable drive is plugged in but can still be accessed. Which of the following command-line tools should the technician use to apply the new policy?

A. grupdate
B. diskpart
C. gpresult
D. net use
Show Answer Hide Answer

Correct Answer: A

https://comptiaexamtest.com/A+220-1002/comptia-a-220-1002-question42/

Selected Answer: A
even chatgpt say's A.

On a standalone workstation, security policies for the local machine and for localaccounts are configured via the Local Security Policy or Local Group Policy snap-in.In an AD domain, they can be configured via Group Policy Objects (GPOs). GPOs are ameans of applying security settings (as well as other administrative settings) across arange of computers and users. per the offical comptia study guide that was purchased from their site.
You try other websites guys. Still the answer is B. It's what Comptia wants.

Assign a policy to a group. Policy assignment to groups lets you assign a policy to a group of users, such as a security group or distribution list.

so you have a group policy in place you can then assign a security policy within the group policy.

comments.content:
Wrong way around, Domain policy will always override the same local policy, otherwise to get around any GPO in a domain environment you could just set a local policy on your PC and do whatever you wanted.
Also with a group policy you can just make on change from the domain controller and push it out to all machines at once - co no interruptions for users as it will just automatically apply at next logon

No it doesn't when joined to a domain.
Local 
Site
Domain 
Ou
Precedence from bottom to top.

discussion.content: Local security policy overwrites domain policy, so I think the answer is correct.
Topic 2 = garbage answers

I agree, It should be Group Policy because then you don't have to spend time logging on to every person's computer or remoting in which depending on the setup could take up more time and bother employees.
Could actually be firewall, permissions and even an ip that hasn't get been renewed.
This is correct, I believe this question refers to Professor Messer's explanation of how firewall settings change based on public vs private locations.
Is it possible the computer got infected by malware like a rootkit while using free Wifi and it changed the firewall settings? just asking, don't be mean...
Anyone mind explaining this one please?

comments.content: I believe network shares are where your network drive is. As firewall was configured incorrectly either inbound or outbound connections have been disabled which disallows the network drive.

Say you work in a office and sometimes take a company laptop home. Let's also say you have mapped network drives that read and pull data when at the office. Now when you go home. You will see those drives in file explorer, however a red x will be over them. also folders will be blank - unless the user knows the password. Most employees won't have it and usually the laptop is set to auto sign in everytime that laptop boots up. It's how admins keep control.
May be Free WiFi spot has caused the firewall settings to disallow the network drive!

questions.question_text: A user recently connected a Windows laptop to a free WiFi hotspot. After returning to the office, the user cannot access network shares. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause?

choices.C: Location-based settings are not turned on
choices.B: The local firewall settings are incorrect
